Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSI: A Sustainable Community Software Framework for Petascale Earthquake Modeling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Earthquakes have major economic and societal consequences as can be seen from the aftermath of the recent large earthquakes in Japan, Chile, and New Zealand. This multidisciplinary project, which includes both geoscientists, computer scientists, and structural engineers, integrates high-level and middle-level scientific software elements developed by the Southern California Earthquake Center (SCEC) into a software environment for integrated seismic modeling that can be used for seismic hazard analysis. The framework includes integration of community velocity models, codes for dynamic and pseudo-dynamic rupture generation, deterministic and stochastic earthquake engines, and the applications necessary to employ forward simulations in two types of inverse problems: seismic source imaging and full 3D tomography. Modifications to already existing software packages slated to be significantly enhanced in the course of the workflow will allow simulations to be run on petascale machines and allow the better managing of scientific workflows. The work also focuses on software lifecycle issues such as model formation, verification, prediction, and validation and support the use of petascale computers by earthquake scientists. The goal of the project is to facilitate the incorporation of better theory and data into computationally intensive modeling of earthquake processes. Software will be designed to interface smoothly with OpenSHA, as well as OpenSEES, PEER, and NEES. Project partners will also develop and test two computational platforms, one that will have a user-friendly interface for calculating seismographs and the other will generate large suites of simulations for a layered earthquake hazard model. Models will be validated against datasets for 13 well-recorded historic California earthquakes of magnitude 6.0 or higher. The initial API will take advantage of the asynchronous IO features of Fortran 2003 with plans for adding C/C++ and Python interfaces. All codes developed will be open-source and publicly available and software distribution will be accompanied by sample input datasets and example forecast results. Broader impacts include the development of a new generation of time-dependent earthquake forecasts to produce ground-shake hazard maps, partnership with a federal agency and the private sector. It also includes a component of student and postdoctoral training and outreach to user communities. Undergraduate interns, many of whom have historically been from groups under-represented in STEM fields, will be trained in use of the software during an 8-week summer training course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The twin goals of the Software Environment for Integrated Seismic Modeling (SEISM) project were (a) to integrate scientific software elements used to perform physics-based ground motion simulations into a sustainable software ecosystem for seismic hazard analysis, and (b) to release the SEISM software for community use as open-source scientific software. Our software ecosystem now sustains dozens of research groups and supports hundreds of downloads by an ever-widening community of users.

Intellectual Merit. The SEISM software ecosystem incorporates scientific software elements for developing and managing unified community velocity models, codes for dynamic and pseudo-dynamic rupture generation, deterministic and stochastic earthquake simulation engines, and software tools needed to improve seismic velocity models using full-3D tomography.

The SEISM project developed the Broadband Platform, a general-use simulator that combines low-frequency simulations in a 1-D medium with high-frequency, stochastic simulations. The project continued the long-term development of two general-use, deterministic 3-D earthquake simulators, Hercules and AWP-ODC. It adapted the latter to drive the reciprocity-based CyberShake platform, which generates the large ensembles of simulations (>108 seismograms) needed for Probabilistic Seismic Hazard Analysis. The project is leading the scientific transition from the current equation-based hazard estimates to simulation-based prediction methods.

Nonlinear simulations by the SEISM collaboration show that nonlinearity in the fault zone is important even for conservative values of cohesion, indicating that current simulations based on a linear behavior of rocks are over-predicting the level of ground motion in the Los Angeles Basin during future large earthquakes on the southern San Andreas Fault. These results have far-reaching implications for earthquake emergency planning scenarios, which have so far been based on ground motions predicted with linear models, such as the damage scenario of the 2008 Great California ShakeOut.

Broader Impacts. SEISM researchers are pushing to incorporate better computational tools into the practice of seismic hazard analysis. A good example was the use of the SCEC Broadband Platform by an industry-led collaboration studying seismic hazards, documented in the 2015 Jan/Feb Seismological Research Letters special focus issue. These engineering activities are supported with public open-source software release of the SCEC Broadband Platform, along with carefully constructed verification and validation test inputs, and test results. This collaboration has led to quantitative evaluation procedures for evaluating new ground motion simulation methods.

The project helped to motivate and educate a diverse scientific workforce from undergraduates to early-career level researchers, engineers, and software developers, to integrate system science with high-performance computing. It has trained a workforce in the multi-disciplinary skills needed to contribute to computational geoscientific research. Project graduate students have accepted jobs in both geoscientific and computer science positions.

An example of a broader impact is the collaboration initiated with researchers at the Universidad de los Andes in Bogotá, Colombia, and the continuation of a collaboration with former CMU PhD Student Dorian Restrepo, now an Assistant Professor at Universidad EAFIT in Medellín, Colombia. These collaborations led to the development of the first seismic velocity model for the region of the Aburrá Valley in Colombia, and the group now has plans to develop a similar model for the Cundinamarca Plain, which includes the capital city of Bogota, with colleagues from Universidad de los Andes. The Aburrá Valley model has been used as a test bed for the implementation of a Virtual Topography approach to model the effects of the surface relief in regional-scale earthquake ground motion simulation, a key new component in the continued development of the simulation code Hercules, within the High-F software framework.

SEISM has provided the computational framework for collaborative activities with interdisciplinary teams that include geoscientists, computer scientists, software developers, and earthquake engineers. Through well-designed scientific and computational goals, and selected validation activities, participants from these disciplines have been working together to construct a software environment for integrated seismic modeling that can produce authoritative information valuable in preparing society for earthquakes and helping protect against their effects.
